data.text: Using Panniers for Bikepacking?

Anyone found any decent panniers for off-road riding? Standard ones all seem to rattle and bounce around, often breaking at the clips. I'll be taking a laptop on a long-term tour and feel like the most protected storage space would be a rear pannier. Also open to any other suggestions on better ways to carry the laptop too. Cheers!
That's a great question, Joshua. I'll be following.
data.author: David Dean

data.text: Following has same issue this weekend gravel Ortlieb‚Äôs
data.author: Jake Coley

data.text: i have these panniers are they bad?
data.author: Steven Murdoch

data.text: I run them on a trek front rack but thinking about modifying the bottom clips to sit closer or maybe strapping the lower part of them to the rack so they hug tighter but for the price I feel like Ortlieb should have already problem solved that lol
data.author: Jake Coley

data.text: Ortleb bags with a bungie around the midsection. Nothing removable is going to be solidly anchored.
data.author: Kevin Merrill

data.text: Will be going for a bungie option!
data.author: Joshua Kian

data.text: Ortleib gravel packs are pretty solid off road
data.author: Josh Govier

data.text: Whatever pannier you choose, maybe put the laptop in a big bubblewrap envelope ? (like the ones that Amazon uses). Or something else made of foam to protect.
data.author: Pierre Moreels

data.text:
https://www.pelican.com/ca/en/product/cases/laptop-case/hardback/1075
1075 HardBack Laptop Case | Pelican
pelican.com
data.author: Chris Hubick

data.text: We've got a hard case but the additional foam/bubble wrap is a good idea
data.author: Joshua Kian

data.text: Depending on frame and laptop sizing, keeping it in a a frame bag may be better. Less direct vibrations there. I hope laptop has an SSD, as that'll be a lot more durable than a HD.
data.author: Jeremy Lawrence

data.text: It does have an SSD. All my external harddrives are HDD though... think this will be an issue for touring?
data.author: Joshua Kian

data.text: , you can wrap the extra HDs up for protection. But SSDs would be safer/more expensive. Another option for backup is large capacity SD cards. HDs don't like vibrations.
data.author: Jeremy Lawrence

data.text: Tailfin? Not cheap but works
data.author: Matt Holly

data.text: https://aeroe.com Not sure how big your laptop is but Aeroe is great for non paved riding. You could get a sling or light backpack too if you don‚Äôt mind riding like that. Or maybe reorganize the storage and put your laptop in a frame bag.
data.author: Matthew Condra

data.text: I agree ortlieb gravel bags were great
data.author: Brian Steven Wagner
Brian Steven Wagner
Darryl Gottselig

data.text: how many litres are your Ortlieb panniers? And front bags?
data.author: Marlena Maier

data.text: ortlieb gravels packs 25 litres. Front sacks are 6 litres.
data.author: Darryl Gottselig

data.text: I have purchased additional Ortleib clips, so there are 2 clips which hold the bottom of my panniers to the rack. Much more secure than the single clip on each side.
data.author: Jason Malone

data.text: the gravel bags come with two clips on the bottom but the classic touring bags only come with one.
data.author: Brian Steven Wagner

data.text: I was going to give Jason Malone‚Äôs idea as well. Because this way you can pay half of the price of the gravel bags if you buy a pair of used front rollers. I did the same.
data.author: Alex Young

data.text: yes definitely, I have the gravel bags with the two clips and with the top clips set up correctly and out as far as the bars will allow, it locks up tight to my rack and i keep them on the lower horizontal bar. I recently looked at used classic rollers to see if they are any larger, they aren‚Äôt, but thought about adding a second clip to each bag if i did go with the classic bags. By the way if those bags rattled at all they would be gone, I can‚Äôt stand rattling.
data.author: Brian Steven Wagner

data.text: Do you need a laptop for something in particular? I just take an iPad Mini (not the best for photo editing) but it‚Äôs lighter and tougher (especially in its case) than my laptop‚Äîand if it breaks, it was about a tenth the cost of my laptop.
data.author: Jacquie Gaudet

data.text: , an iPad big enough to work with and with enough storage can cost more than most folk's laptops. üò≥ it'll still be compromised compared to a laptop, software wise. A laptop with an SSD will be almost as robust.
data.author: Jeremy Lawrence

data.text: It's for video editing. I don't actually know the current capabilities of tablets but I couldn't get by with one.
data.author: Joshua Kian

data.text: I wondered if that was the reason. I do minor edits on the road and major when I‚Äôm home, but I‚Äôm just doing still photography and my CycleBlaze journal. That‚Äôs enough screen time for me.
data.author: Jacquie Gaudet

data.text: I'm really envious of photographers working from tablets away. Seems like a nice way to do things. Our ride will be broken up by pit stops where we stop to edit. Though we actually write articles from the tent üòÖ
data.author: Joshua Kian

data.text: Sounds interesting. I‚Äôve always had a time limit that I try to squeeze in as much as possible. Too many places to go!
data.author: Jacquie Gaudet

data.text: the trips I‚Äôve used them have been a mixed bag of weather. On the trip with the pics above we had temps getting down to freezing the first night. So far they are great space wise. Haven‚Äôt had any issues on needing more room

data.author: Wes Mendenhall

data.text: I've had good luck overall with Gravel Ortliebs. Haven't had a pannier fall off and it's pretty rare for the lower clips to bounce off their proper location. What's more important is how you carry your laptop. Pack it tightly in your pannier in a padded case. SSD laptops are the way to go for durability. My 2014 MacBook Air has been through hell and back on my bike and I'm still using daily...
data.author: Derek Poshtar

data.text: I have full set of Thule ones with sides on so bags can clip top and bottom and stay put
data.author: Chris Healey

data.text: Have had good experience with Thule in the past oo
data.author: Joshua Kian
Rob Halliday

data.text: Arkel panniers won‚Äôt rattle off. Ever. Make sure your racks are on with loctite ( or welded on like ToutTerrain)
data.author: Tom Cavan

data.text: the very best. Genius locking system.
data.author: Lee Veinotte

data.text: Ortleib Gravel Packs, plus wrap your rack around all the contact points with electrical tape (overlap like bar tape) to make a nice tight fit with a bit of cushioning.
data.author: David Rossi
David Rossi

data.text:
Must be the trick (taping) because my first extended rough gravel ride out here in southern AZ broke the clip on one of my new Ortlieb gravel packs. More experienced riders in our terrain here don‚Äôt recommend them. I‚Äôm going with a dry bag mounted on top of the rack. Ordered a dry bag protector and will give that a try. https://rockgeist.com/product/armadillo-dry-bag-protector/
Armadillo Dry Bag Protector | Rockgeist Bikepack USA
rockgeist.com
data.author: Dean Wolfgang

data.text: I did the extremely rocky Tasmanian Trail with the Ortleib Gravel Packs, as well as many other trails. It does also depend on the design of the rack (ideally all rails sit flat).
data.author: David Rossi

data.text: Arkel make some good ones. These are theire "dri-lites" prob a bit small for a laptop but they do make others more for touring. I also just add a tension strap to stabilize.
data.author: Jeff Emrich

data.text: Lots of folks are suggesting the Ortlieb Gravel Packs and also the (probably superior for off-road) Microwave panniers, but you're not going to fit a laptop in either of those.... I have a 13" XPS in a Thule Gauntlet and also a set of Gravel Packs, and there's no way it would fit in those with or without the case. I can't see an 11" laptop being much better. I slide it into the pocket in the back of a set of standard Ortlieb Back Rollers - but the roughest terrain we ride with that particular setup is gravel/rail trail.
data.author: Dave Henderson

data.text: Topeak mdx
data.author: James Seliger

data.text: Relevate makes great panniers.
data.author: Tom Kendall

data.text: Arkel dry-lites are basically dry bag panniers held on with velcro straps and bungee hooks. The only thing rigid in them are a few replaceable wooden dowels.
data.author: Leif Warner
Andy Reed

data.text:
Just ordered these so can‚Äôt vouch how they are but heard good things. https://www.stealthbikebags.com/
Bikepacking Bags | MTB Road Gravel | Stealth Bike Bags
stealthbikebags.com
data.author: Rex Villanueva

data.text:
Lots of people bungee around the bag, back to the rack. I was looking to potentially add another hook, but it probably will not stop the rattle and take adjusting at the on and off. Ortlieb is very adjustable. https://youtu.be/csV0rVY-moU
Ortlieb's Quick Lock Systems Explained
youtube.com
data.author: Ian Rose

data.text: Ortlieb
data.author: John Mcalister

data.text: I‚Äôve taken ortlieb back roller classics with no issues with the clips. Also you can install extra bottom clips for additional security Taping the rack at the clip contact points with reduce rack rub and rattling And increase security.
data.author: Sam Marron

data.text: Vaude Aqua Back. I find them super sturdy and don't rattle around üòä

data.text: handlebar bag.
data.author: Lucas Ehster

data.text: I commuted for years along bumpy tracks with a Vaude aqua back. Kept my lap top dry and happy. I‚Äôd also recommend slipping it into a cheap light foam case such as you can buy for online ¬£10 to keep it shiny.
data.author: Katie McTavish

data.text:
I bought these and sold my ortleibs. Sooo much better. If you do get them, you need to apply shoe goo to the back after a couple of rides after you figure out where they rub on the rack. They're also way lighter. https://www.rei.com/product/167661/rei-co-op-link-pannier-single
REI Co-op Link Pannier - Single | REI Co-op

data.text: So many awesome suggestions - thanks everyone! Will take a look through.
data.author: Joshua Kian

data.text: Standard ones by what company ?? Ortlieb are the the best.. They make spring loaded connectors that are adjustable so the panniers can be attached at different angles to other manufacturers frames. They also make inserts for the clamps to use on different size pannier frame posts so they don‚Äôt rattle.
data.author: Michael Armalavage

data.text: Check out Lone Peak Packs

data.text: I also think that JPaks LLC makes a laptop bag, otherwise he does custom work too.
